_header: Sore I sigh and sore I may

BodDou52.First Lines:
Sore I syke & well I mayffor thre thynges þat comyn
                    ay…
BodDou52.Last Lines:
…þe thrydde is most careI not ner whider I schall
                    fare
BodDou52.Note:
Incomplete: lines 3-4 occur on f. 20v and line 6 on f.
                    24.
BodDou52.Editions:
Pantin,  William A. 
             “A Medieval Collection of Latin and English Proverbs…from Rylands
                Latin MS. 394.” 
             Bulletin of the John Rylands Library
         14 (1930): 81-114: 101.
Förster,  Max. 
             “Die Mittelenglische Sprichwörtersammlung in Douce 52.” 
             Festschrift zum XII Deutschen Neuphilolgentage in München
                1906.
            E. Stollreither, ed. 
         Erlangen (1906): 40-64: 49, 51.

RylandsLat394.Transcription:
Sore y sye & sore I mayfor þre þynges me comys
                    aldayÞe ton is þat I shal henþe toþer is wot not
                    whenþe þrydde is my most careI not wheder I shal
                    fare
RylandsLat394.Note:
Written three long lines, two verse lines for each, translating
                        ‘Sunt tria que vere faciunt me sepe dolere…’, which
                    follows.
RylandsLat394.Attributed Title: Sore y syke and sore y may (title or false start, f. 13)
RylandsLat394.Editions:
Pantin,  William A. 
             “A Medieval Collection of Latin and English Proverbs…from Rylands
                Latin MS. 394.” 
             Bulletin of the John Rylands Library
         14 (1930): 81-114: 101.
